question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to analyze film beyond the plot, focusing on visual elements like framing and color to understand deeper meanings. I also gained insight into how Chinese cinema reflects regional and historical shifts, especially through directors like Jia Zhangke. Lastly, I learned to appreciate minimalism and silence in film as powerful storytelling tools. Before this class, I had no experience with film analysis, and, quite frankly, did not appreciate them to the level that I do now.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about how to watch movies through a critical lens by examining the sound design and the cinematography. I also learned about how to place the films in a historical context surrounding Hong Kong, Taiwan, and China. I also learned about a bunch of new directors and their style.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, the biggest knowledge I gained was about East Asian cinema in general, including how political, social, and economic factors shape film and how filmmaking conventions vary by region---I was really interested by the Taiwanese New Cinema movement especially. Additionally, I learned how to analyze films and talk about films in an academic way, paying close attention to cinematography, sound, script, etc. Finally, I learned about many directors I had never heard of before that I now love to watch!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A course that encompasses a breadth of material to critically interrogate what constitutes "story" and to whom. I learned about Eastern vs. Western storytelling modalities and the role of Orientalism in framing narratives in faraway lands through our unit on A Thousand and One Nights, as well as questioning if it is possible, in the guise of the modern novel with its emphasis on human consumption and emotion, to tell a story with a non-human subject by exploring the place of Sun Wu Kong in the Chinese literary canon. Turning our attention to familiar European storytelling traditions, we also studied the morphology of fairytales, as explicated by Vladimir Propp, and the socio-psychological imperatives baked into the archetypes of "fairy stories," as posited by Tolkien. We likewise explored the ways the framework of game changes narratives structures by imposing ludology, rather than temporality, to guide stories.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The central component of this class is to write nine essays centered around a storyworld of your choosing, fleshing out various aspects of the world to understand the cogs that make the machine of story function. These essays are a joy to write, as they are fueled by student interest, and they are also an essential tool for learning to apply the various methodologies and modalities gone over in lecture. Having these available as an open forum for everyone to look at each other's work promoted student engagement in our own storyworlds as well as close-readings of our peers, since we could comment and generate dialogue on each other's posts. Furthermore, class featured a mix of lecture and seminar-style engagement, which enabled us to wrangle with concepts for ourselves and develop our own nuanced opinions on how the art of worldbuilding and the various cultural heritages it draws upon can be done.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As stated above, the nine storyworld blog posts were both fun to write and fun to read. I enjoyed following along storyworlds familiar and new through the eyes of my peers and their analyses of what makes these worlds shine or fall flat. I immensely enjoyed lecture and the various scratchpad exercises (tell a story in 6 words, craft a mystery, map archetypes to a fairytale, "Are all stories bound up in power, property, and domination?" etc). done with my peers. These encouraged us to debate the elements of story and form our own opinions on how we form and digest narratives. Dr. Chow's warm demeanor and razor-sharp intellect transform this class from an academic exercise to a veritable intellectual family.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to create meaning in video, from both the perspective of the maker and the viewer. I also learned about the ways that video can be used to convey a political message as well as new ways of thinking about what is meaningful and how to create meaning through my video work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I was able to expand my way of thinking on many topics that I once thought I knew everything about. I'm amazed by how Professor Jenny Lion was able to take seemingly widespread concepts and dig deeply into what they meant to our society, so much so that we were able to produce creative video art through examining the contexts of everything we discussed within the course. In Video Art and Politics, I developed a deeper understanding of how moving images can function as both aesthetic expression and political intervention. The course expanded my critical lens as a media maker and viewer. Three specific things I learned are:- The Power of Visual Rhetoric – I gained insight into how visual language, framing, and editing choices can shape political meaning and influence audiences emotionally and intellectually. This helped me reflect more intentionally on my own creative decisions and the messages they convey.- Expanded Definitions of Activism and Art – I learned how artists and filmmakers use nontraditional forms, such as video installations, essay films, and acts of tactical media, as political tools. These works challenged me to rethink the boundaries of what counts as political art and to appreciate the role of experimentation in social critique.- Process as Political Practice – Through the final project and class discussions, I understood how the process of making video art (including collaboration, research, and engagement with communities) can itself be a political act. This insight will continue to shape how I approach media production and storytelling in socially engaged contexts.

response_text: Jenny very much prompted open discussion and wanted us to really critique each other's work properly, not just saying what we liked about the piece. But asking the person whose work it was really what do they need to know, what will help them? I feel like the the first artists using video in the 70s that she showed us were very intriguing and I really enjoyed being exposed to them. Also, Jenny co-ordinated artists to come speak to our class like Wendy Clarke who did The Love Tapes. I found her visit so inspiring that I decided to recreate her work for myself and Jenny kindly connected me with Wendy and formed that connection and gave me lots of advice on how to carry it out respectfully and properly. Jenny said this class is basically about how to change the world - and I really felt like I learnt a lot about activism and how to use my skills in video for things I care about and to help others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment of Video Art and Politics was deeply engaging and thoughtfully designed to support both creative exploration and critical thinking. The instructor fostered a space that encouraged experimentation, open dialogue, and personal connection to the material, which was crucial for a course dealing with both art and sociopolitical issues.
One of the most impactful components was the balance between theory and practice—readings and screenings provided historical and conceptual context, while creative assignments allowed us to respond artistically. This dual approach helped me internalize complex ideas through hands-on application. I also appreciated the peer feedback sessions and in-class critiques, which created a collaborative and supportive environment. Hearing from others enriched my perspective and gave me practical suggestions to refine my work.For future years, I’d definitely keep the final project format that allowed us to define our own intervention and work across mediums. It encouraged risk-taking and personal investment, making the course feel both rigorous and meaningful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How film works. How to do direct animation. How to edit the film with Steenbeck. How to load, and shoot with Bolex 16. How to develop Soundstock and TriX.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was very helpful in developing technical skills related to filmmaking, editing, film processing, and shooting. Working in the darkroom was a very informative hands-on experience, as was using the Steenbeck manual editing table to splice and cut together films physically. In addition to the Steenbeck editing techniques, we were taught how to use Adobe Lightroom to edit our films digitally. I also got comfortable using the Bolex camera while making films for the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hill provided a good balance of lecturing (on the history, theory, technology, etc. of filmmaking) and practical application of the concepts we learned in class. I appreciated this structure and always felt I had a strong informational basis before going out and practicing filmmaking techniques myself. Each class session felt like a constructive progression from the previous one. I think the syllabus was laid out nicely as it allowed for a smooth transition between topics and reflected our growing experience over the course of the semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a fun intro level course to 16mm film! If you want time to do some hands on art, this is the place. Shooting and developing can be a little stressful, but Madison was always very responsive and helpful when reached out to. Make sure you take notes in class to prepare for shooting, and start your projects far before they are due.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course! Madison is a wonderful instructor who will introduce you to the joys and intricacies of analog filmmaking. Although analog can be frustrating at times, this course allows you to experience both the excitement of getting it right (film turning out as intended) and the mistakes that are inherent to 16mm filmmaking, without the stress of having to be the perfect filmmaker. Instead, grace is given for all students to learn the medium and experiment with their own creative impulses.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Milligan was one of the most helpful and knowledgeable professors I’ve had at my time at Duke- and I’m a BME major. He had a very clear and detailed lesson plan that got introductory filmmakers caught up with the more advanced students in the class, and even offered workshops on various things like lighting, camera work, and editing throughout the year to bolster our learning. I think it was so cool we were able to use the film studio for every class, as instead of just watching and discussing film pieces we were able to create and learn as we made film together.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got a lot better at my craft. Getting to practice it for a whole semester, following my own methodology, is amazing and such a privilege!I learned how to present my progress. Progress comes in all forms, and sometimes it isn't as tangible or immediately noticeable so it must be communicated verbally instead. But this communication, whether it is in the form of a Powerpoint or spoken word, is important so that the class can give good feedback and my involvement is still evident.I learned how to plan a semester-long project from start to finish. I've never done something like this before because the longest project I've ever completed was about half a semester long, with pre-made guidelines. Writing my own syllabus was a new exercise for me. I also learned how to set goals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think the skill I most developed over the course of this semester was self-discipline. In creating my short film, I really had to organize my time effectively and motivate myself to keep on track, and I felt like this course helped us structure the development of this skill well. I also learned a lot about the process of production and all the little administrative tasks that go into making a film. Finally, I got better at presenting unfinished works in front of people. Normally, in the past, I would only ever show finished works. However, to receive valuable feedback, I have realized that showing progress to people along the way is really important.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was exposed to a wide variety of popular queer media, most of which I had not seen yet and was grateful to have experienced now. I think I got much more accustomed to film theory and ideas, and writing critically about films, since I’d never taken a film centric class prior to this one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze cinema using the lens of queer theory, how to create a zine, and how to write about movies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new perspectives about queerness and how it is portrayed in media. I learned how to critically analyze LGBTQ media on my own, and through experiencing queer media learned a lot of queer history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a few different film techniques that can be used to generate various feelings for the viewer. I also learned about the history of expression and repression in queer media, particularly in the context of the Hays code. I also learned how different people define and express their identity, which I felt that the discord posts facilitated.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Different points to start on when analyzing a film. 
2. How to combine literature work into film analysis
3. Comparison between films

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Archer did a wonderful job facilitating fruitful discussions in class and on Discord. I liked the format -- having a discussion and then watching a film was a great way to proceed through the class and keep us interested.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed hearing about other people's opinions of the films during class discussions. The discord responses were a good way to reflect on the assigned films and readings. My favorite part of the course was probably the midterm (zine), which was really fun to make.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes, the structure of the course was fantastic. To split screenings and discussion both between class and home kept me engaged with the material throughout the week and fostered reflection. Discussions in class often left me with new insights and rarely dragged on for too long.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that discussion was very open, and that Professor Boyette encouraged us to explore alternative methods of thinking about film, such as making zines and creating our own film proposal, which I found much more interesting than just writing a midterm/final essay.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the Discord-hosted forum, for one because it felt like an actual discussion space due to it not being hosted on an academic site, and secondly because I loved hearing what my classmates were thinking about the movies we watched since we couldn’t discuss immediately after the showing. I also loved the midterm zine and this should definitely be kept!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you’re wanting to explore queer film and film theory, take the course! It’s a great introduction. As a queer individual who grew up not really engaging in queer histories and popular culture, I enjoyed getting to understand queer lived experiences through this angle.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great introduction to the world of film in general with diverse topics and films. Many of the films beautifully portray the queer experience and offer a starting point for important conversations within the community. You don't need to know anything about films or LGBTQ+ culture before taking this class, as it is all covered and addressed week by week. If you are looking for a class to fill an empty slot, I highly recommend this one!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learn how Disney was set up, the history of Disney, and how they expand their brand through synergy.
I also learn what is diegesis and non-diegesis music and some terminology of describing the music. And also experience how music can play a narrative role in film.
I know how Disney films are characterized into different eras and know the features of films in different eras.
I also know what theme park music is and how theme park music can engage visitors.
I know the term nostalgia and how Disney utilizes it.
Three act structure
I learned how to analyze the music by using terms. When I watch a film now, I pay more attention to the background music, and how they play the role to perfect the film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was a great introduction into understanding film on a more technical level! We began with elements of movies like mise-en scene and cinematography and worked our way into more specific details like acting and sound design. This course has fundamentally changed the way I think about movies and made them so much more fun to watch! For example, for the film Punch Drunk Love, before this course, I would have seen it simply as a quirky and confusing romcom. However, after paying attention to things like cinematography, shot composition, the use of a telephoto lens, etc. it took on a whole new meaning and became so much more engaging to watch. Really grateful for this course helping me to put general intuition about a film into clear meaning and technical wording!One of my favorite things we learned about this semester was looking at the evolution and history of film. The course itself follows this progression in the movies we watch. It was really cool to watch clips of earlier work and inspiration for a certain film and then watch the film itself. This gave us a great perspective on where some of these creative and innovative ideas in cinema came from.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the formal elements of film, such as cinematography and mise-en-scene; I also learned to think critically about sound design and the role of directors and actors; and I learned to write formal analyses of films.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze films, different things to look for when watching films, and a newfound respect for filmmaking as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The skills to identify and analyze formal elements in films, the history of film as an art and as a technology, and the production process of a film.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course to fulfill the ALP Trinity requirement! question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in films--either you are a movie fan or someone who is pursuing a degree in film studies--I definitely recommend taking this class with Dr. Cason. Professor Cason is super accessible and helpful, and this class provides you with a taste of film analysis and film theory in a relatively low-stake environment where a diverse range of opinions and creativity collides. It will be a wonderful choice if you are seeking to get credits for humanities/art classes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. A better understanding of cinema as an entity through time since its conception
2. A stronger sense of what matters to filmmakers at various points in time and how that manifests in their work

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read film theory papers and understand them in regard to their historical background. I also learned how film theorist engage with one another over the years and changed ideologies with the advent of new technologies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about major film theorists and their theories, including bell hooks, Bazin, Siegfried Kracauer and Erwin Panofsky. I learned how to write a paper about theory and I learned how to write and analyze films through various theoretical lenses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Overall, I gained a new understanding for how film theory has emerged and changed over time. Before, I knew film theory only from bits and pieces that I had read (out of context) in other courses, but this course really helped to frame and contextualize theory as a whole. I most enjoyed the semiotics unit and how investigating cinema as a language influenced more modern theorists in thinking about the socio-political impacts of film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned some historical background on cinema and early film, as well as more applied techniques like understanding film production/construction of shots/the effect they have and how to critically evaluate the position a film might have relative to its social/political context.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: From classical film theory to modern and contemporary film theory. Learned how to read theories and analyze films with the theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the history and ideologies surrounding specific figures who have contributed to the development of film theory. I feel that my understanding of realism and identity as it relates to cinema strengthened after contextualizing films with in-class lectures. Finally, I had the opportunity to expand upon and adapt a paper to fit new criteria. I appreciated the space to rework and build a paper after the feedback stage as I often abandon papers once they are submitted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this media theory course, I gained a deep understanding of media's evolution, from foundational debates about writing and mediation to contemporary digital culture. The course equipped me with critical frameworks to analyze how different media forms - from print to digital platforms - shape human experience and social relationships. Key theoretical concepts like technological determinism, cultural techniques, and media archaeology enhanced my ability to examine the complex interplay between media, technology, and society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class has given me a whole new understanding of the concept of media. Because before I chose this major, I knew almost nothing about media. In this class, I learned a lot about the concept of media and the historical process of media. In particular, I am deeply impressed by McLuhan's theory. He taught me that media can influence our perception and shape our society. And I also realized commodification and entertainment, it makes me know that we need to keep our own judgment in the market to find the real value

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me so many useful skills, whether I decide to be a production manager for theater or not. Through the books we read, like Dan Heath's Upstream and Fearless Negotiating by Michael C. Donaldson, I learned how to preemptively stop problems from occurring, as well as how to negotiate and the most effective way to do so. Through our assignments, I learned how to organize and put together a calendar with important dates and events, as well as how to make a budget for both mainstage and repertory theater shows, which is a very useful skill. Knowing how to work with money and budget everything accurately is a skill important to all aspects of life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: That the class is is a lot of outside work which may be cumbersome if you also have a class that eats up a lot of your time. Overall though, if you have any interest in theater or management the class is very interesting. If you have no background in theater the class does cover most of what you would need to know. The knowledge gained from the class can be applicable in areas outside of theater as well, so it is still worthwhile. The class is pretty chill and Thom is very approachable, plus you get to enjoy two comped shows, one at the DPAC with a Q&A session with the cast and crew after, and another with the Duke Theater Studies Show. Additionally, Thom lines up a good selection of guest speakers with quality inside knowledge and stories which were interesting every time. For those reasons I recommend the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to analyze film beyond the plot, focusing on visual elements like framing and color to understand deeper meanings. I also gained insight into how Chinese cinema reflects regional and historical shifts, especially through directors like Jia Zhangke. Lastly, I learned to appreciate minimalism and silence in film as powerful storytelling tools. Before this class, I had no experience with film analysis, and, quite frankly, did not appreciate them to the level that I do now.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned about how to place the films in a historical context surrounding Hong Kong, Taiwan, and China. I also learned about a bunch of new directors and their style.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, the biggest knowledge I gained was about East Asian cinema in general, including how political, social, and economic factors shape film and how filmmaking conventions vary by region---I was really interested by the Taiwanese New Cinema movement especially. Additionally, I learned how to analyze films and talk about films in an academic way, paying close attention to cinematography, sound, script, etc. Finally, I learned about many directors I had never heard of before that I now love to watch!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A course that encompasses a breadth of material to critically interrogate what constitutes "story" and to whom. I learned about Eastern vs. Western storytelling modalities and the role of Orientalism in framing narratives in faraway lands through our unit on A Thousand and One Nights, as well as questioning if it is possible, in the guise of the modern novel with its emphasis on human consumption and emotion, to tell a story with a non-human subject by exploring the place of Sun Wu Kong in the Chinese literary canon. Turning our attention to familiar European storytelling traditions, we also studied the morphology of fairytales, as explicated by Vladimir Propp, and the socio-psychological imperatives baked into the archetypes of "fairy stories," as posited by Tolkien. We likewise explored the ways the framework of game changes narratives structures by imposing ludology, rather than temporality, to guide stories.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The central component of this class is to write nine essays centered around a storyworld of your choosing, fleshing out various aspects of the world to understand the cogs that make the machine of story function. These essays are a joy to write, as they are fueled by student interest, and they are also an essential tool for learning to apply the various methodologies and modalities gone over in lecture. Having these available as an open forum for everyone to look at each other's work promoted student engagement in our own storyworlds as well as close-readings of our peers, since we could comment and generate dialogue on each other's posts. Furthermore, class featured a mix of lecture and seminar-style engagement, which enabled us to wrangle with concepts for ourselves and develop our own nuanced opinions on how the art of worldbuilding and the various cultural heritages it draws upon can be done.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As stated above, the nine storyworld blog posts were both fun to write and fun to read. I enjoyed following along storyworlds familiar and new through the eyes of my peers and their analyses of what makes these worlds shine or fall flat. I immensely enjoyed lecture and the various scratchpad exercises (tell a story in 6 words, craft a mystery, map archetypes to a fairytale, "Are all stories bound up in power, property, and domination?" etc). done with my peers. These encouraged us to debate the elements of story and form our own opinions on how we form and digest narratives. Dr. Chow's warm demeanor and razor-sharp intellect transform this class from an academic exercise to a veritable intellectual family.

response_text: I liked Coates' teaching style - some film clips, some discussion, some lecture. I really liked how we had four in-class film screening days - we watched "The Conjuring," "Star Wars," "God's Not Dead," and "Kumaré." I liked our "mini review" assignments, where you basically produce a 7-minute film review using a class reading from that specific unit and you have to argue why it should be considered religious. The movies and clips we'd watch in class were more obviously religious, so this was a chance for us to get creative and find something that seems secular and apply it to our learnings.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
This is such a unique course, and was a wonderful experience! I think the horror genre is fascinating, though I hadn't had much contact with it previously, and it's great that we got to engage with it in an academic context. Professor Bell was great, and I had so much fun with this class. There's a lot of writing, but I think that's a good part of the class. Making myself dive into writing for a new medium (as I had no previous experience with screenwriting) is what really started to give me a sense for what goes into a script.
Stay on top of your long script at the end, though. Checkpoints are built into the class, so don't get behind on them, because that 80 page script is very manageable if broken up over multiple weeks, but very scary if you've let it pile up!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I obtained skills for analyzing Shakespeare, discussing Shakespeare, and viewing adaptations critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had a casual interest in Shakespeare prior to this course, but this course taught me to really dive deeply into his works in ways I have not before. I learned a lot about the historical context behind Shakespeare plays and how that context can be recontextualized through adaptation for a modern audience. I really enjoyed this class as a means of thinking more deeply about film as a medium and how it connects to more historical mediums like plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close and wide engagement with Shakespeare in text, across genre/culture in adaptation through various mediums, and written articulation of thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about film techniques (sound, camera angles, mise en scene, etc.) which I did not know much about before
2. I learned about the different definitions of what it means for a movie to be an "adaptation" of something and that adaptations are not merely derivative of the text
3. I learned how to closely analyze the language Shakespeare uses throughout his texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze films which is something I've never done before, especially putting them in conversation with texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I never know what to write for this question because it is hard to come up with a new method or skill you learn in every class. I really enjoyed all of the plays though. I suppose something I learned was just how much Shakespeare recycled themes and character tropes. I think it was fun to be able to see traces of his different plays bleeding into each other a little.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We went deep into analyzing Shakespeare texts as well as adaptations. I had never engaged with films like we did in this class, using cinematic terminology to discuss and analyze them. I think overall this made me more observant and a better reader/thinker.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze Shakespeare, Shakespearian films, and how to discuss aspects of Shakespearian literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about film techniques and terminology as well as read some scholarship on films (e.g. Mulvey's 'male gaze' theory). I read and reflected on a diverse range of Shakespeare plays and how they can be adapted into different times and cultures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the freedom we have in when to submit our written responses and what we could write about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the use of "gobbets" as a means of prompting analysis. They're a relatively low-stakes way to engage with whatever we're reading or watching, and I really enjoyed getting the feedback on it. It always felt like our professor was really interested in whatever we wrote about and why it struck us in particular. I also really enjoyed the balance between watching clips to spark discussion and letting us guide discussion naturally through conversation with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek does such an incredible job at facilitating open discussion - he takes everyone's points seriously and is clearly so informed/knowledgeable on these plays. Writing our gobbets (reading responses, 8 total at any point in the semester) allowed me to synthesize my thoughts across the plays and their adaptations, and they were really accessible ways with engaging closely with the week's topics. Derek really made this class so fun, and his selections of the readings/plays/films were fantastic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek made the course extremely conversational, allowing me to develop different perspectives on each text we read and movie we saw. He encouraged people to disagree with him, which left lots of room for independent analytical thought. I would keep this teaching style for future classes. Additionally, watching a variety of different Shakespeare adaptations, some strict and some loose, facilitated my understanding of what it means for a film to be an adaptation. I would continue showing films from different time periods and cultures in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought Derek found a wonderful balance between lecture and seminar, which is something I've struggled with in classes before. He always asked questions to prompt discussion, but also started each class with a 5 ish minute lecture that help put the lesson into context. I absolutely loved this course and think Derek would make a wonderful professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Witten is super interested in what he is teaching which is probably the most effective way to engage your students. I loved discussions, and it was fun to watch clips from the films. I hesitate to say I would keep the same plays in future years, because as much as I enjoyed them all, I think it would be more fun for Professor Witten to get to keep teaching new plays.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like how Professor Witten kept the class very interactive and promoted collaboration among students. He was extremely energetic and excited about the material he was teaching, which made me look forward to this class every day!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was always kind and communicative. He was able to teach the course assignments effectively and efficiently.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that even though it was on the bigger end of a seminar we were able to still have the 'seminar' component through the use small groups and the teacher's ability to lead and engage the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think I mostly enjoyed the balance between professorial commentary and student talking, but sometimes I wish that we as students guided the discussion a little more. I almost wish we got to start with some sort of gauge of how everyone felt about the play/film, and find points of discussion from there.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the balance of text and film was very good, and the separation of units made it so that a good mix of plays were covered. I liked that the course engaged with non-American content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was made stimulating because it allowed me to examine Shakespeare through a variety of lenses, gaining an understanding of both the potential and limitations of Shakespeare's original source material. Additionally, the class's discussion-based nature made it stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

response_text: The level of engagement with Shakespearian texts and films made my level of engagement very high, and as a result, I am now personally invested in learning Shakespearian literature

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Because there isn't a ton of time to work on it in class, it's entirely up  to you to ensure you work on it in a timely manner while balancing your other coursework.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything I learned about film was from this class! I learned how to use Premiere Pro, I learned how to give and take critique on a film, I also learned what to look for while positioning a camera for interviews, or b-roll or anything that’s used in a film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so many things that it's hard to list all of them, especially because Professor Hareth has a way of teaching students both soft and hard skills that are helpful not only in film but in other parts of what it takes to be a successful student. For example, planning a film may seem like easy work, but it actually takes a lot of effort and practice, and you have to learn to be able to take feedback and criticism from your peers. Or, you may start filming something with a vision in mind and then realize things aren't working the way you imagined and think on the spot for ways to correct them. We also learned how to use Premiere Pro, which is much more challenging than I could have known, but without the class I wouldn't have taken the time to learn the skill, which I'm sure will be useful for my future. Lastly, we learned how to use a camera and a tripod, how to frame videos and fix lighting, how to focus on your subjects, and using various audio techniques.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- how to make concepts, film these concepts, and then be in charge of the entire editing and post process
- how to successfully schedule properly and use professional equipment and software
- how to tell a story, how to convey a point, and how to beautifully execute an intention through film

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Mastering Professional Equipment
   I learned to operate the SONY A7iii and Zoom H6/H5 microphones, mastering settings like ISO, aperture, gain levels, and troubleshooting to capture high-quality visuals and audio.2. Adobe Premiere Pro Editing  
   I gained skills in editing, including color correction, audio synchronization, and applying transitions to craft polished, professional videos.3. Leveraging Camera Features* 
   I explored camera techniques like depth of field, focus, and composition to create dynamic, visually compelling shots and enhance storytelling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I honed the skill of delving into unfamiliar topics, conducting thorough research, and crafting compelling stories based on them. The course consistently challenged us to write scripts on subjects we had no personal experience with or prior knowledge of. I gained proficiency in gathering both primary and secondary resources, covering historical contexts, technical details, and cultural backgrounds.Additionally, I mastered the art of writing within tight deadlines. With a weekly writing assignment, I learned to draft quickly and then focus on revisions rather than getting bogged down by details in the initial draft.Lastly, I cultivated the ability to provide constructive feedback to my peers in class. Engaging in script readings and discussions allowed me to refine my communication and comprehension skills while collaborating effectively with my classmates.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the method of reading everybody's work in a roundtable is very effective for this class. It allows the class to remain true to how screenplays are read and understood in the film industry but it also really allowed me to get an understanding of what was effective and what wasn't in a way that I didn't really get from just reading the work on the page. I also really liked that we got to stick with one idea for the majority of the semester. I don't often get to do that in other classes and it really allowed me to dive deep into a plot line and into the characters I was writing. I'm really proud of the final product.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: This course is very cool. You actually learn how to write a screenplay. You start slow and small, with 5- to 10-page short films, and Prof. Bell walks you through the process, so it's not scary. You also read your screenplay in class, and everybody gives feedback. It's vulnerable, but so constructive. You learn so much from your peers in this course. By the end of it, writing an 80-page script is time-consuming, but not super challenging.

Watching and later analyzing the movies was also a lot of fun, and I learned a lot from reading scripts while watching them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Every week the instructor had us write a 2pp-5pp script in accordance with a given theme. We also watched a new movie each week and analyzed its script. Getting feedback really helped me develop my writing skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He made all of us talk in the movie discussions, which forced everyone to be engaged. We did open table reads and watched films as a class. We also had weekly discussion posts that we could all read. I think that Professor Hawkins did an incredible job at engaging the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:

I like the assignments with different theme because it helps give structure to the projects and allow us to explore a specific theme relating to dance film, also helps supply us with inspiration and new ideas about dance film. I think the movement exercises is very helpful for class. It helps bond everyone together and makes students focus on class. It is also helpful for us to think more about dance and movement.

response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: I learned about how to create meaning in video, from both the perspective of the maker and the viewer. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I was able to expand my way of thinking on many topics that I once thought I knew everything about. I'm amazed by how Professor Jenny Lion was able to take seemingly widespread concepts and dig deeply into what they meant to our society, so much so that we were able to produce creative video art through examining the contexts of everything we discussed within the course. In Video Art and Politics, I developed a deeper understanding of how moving images can function as both aesthetic expression and political intervention. The course expanded my critical lens as a media maker and viewer. Three specific things I learned are:- The Power of Visual Rhetoric – I gained insight into how visual language, framing, and editing choices can shape political meaning and influence audiences emotionally and intellectually. This helped me reflect more intentionally on my own creative decisions and the messages they convey.- Expanded Definitions of Activism and Art – I learned how artists and filmmakers use nontraditional forms, such as video installations, essay films, and acts of tactical media, as political tools. These works challenged me to rethink the boundaries of what counts as political art and to appreciate the role of experimentation in social critique.- Process as Political Practice – Through the final project and class discussions, I understood how the process of making video art (including collaboration, research, and engagement with communities) can itself be a political act. This insight will continue to shape how I approach media production and storytelling in socially engaged contexts.

response_text: Jenny very much prompted open discussion and wanted us to really critique each other's work properly, not just saying what we liked about the piece. But asking the person whose work it was really what do they need to know, what will help them? I feel like the the first artists using video in the 70s that she showed us were very intriguing and I really enjoyed being exposed to them. Also, Jenny co-ordinated artists to come speak to our class like Wendy Clarke who did The Love Tapes. I found her visit so inspiring that I decided to recreate her work for myself and Jenny kindly connected me with Wendy and formed that connection and gave me lots of advice on how to carry it out respectfully and properly. Jenny said this class is basically about how to change the world - and I really felt like I learnt a lot about activism and how to use my skills in video for things I care about and to help others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment of Video Art and Politics was deeply engaging and thoughtfully designed to support both creative exploration and critical thinking. The instructor fostered a space that encouraged experimentation, open dialogue, and personal connection to the material, which was crucial for a course dealing with both art and sociopolitical issues.
One of the most impactful components was the balance between theory and practice—readings and screenings provided historical and conceptual context, while creative assignments allowed us to respond artistically. This dual approach helped me internalize complex ideas through hands-on application. I also appreciated the peer feedback sessions and in-class critiques, which created a collaborative and supportive environment. Hearing from others enriched my perspective and gave me practical suggestions to refine my work.For future years, I’d definitely keep the final project format that allowed us to define our own intervention and work across mediums. It encouraged risk-taking and personal investment, making the course feel both rigorous and meaningful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was very helpful in developing technical skills related to filmmaking, editing, film processing, and shooting. Working in the darkroom was a very informative hands-on experience, as was using the Steenbeck manual editing table to splice and cut together films physically. In addition to the Steenbeck editing techniques, we were taught how to use Adobe Lightroom to edit our films digitally. I also got comfortable using the Bolex camera while making films for the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course! Madison is a wonderful instructor who will introduce you to the joys and intricacies of analog filmmaking. Although analog can be frustrating at times, this course allows you to experience both the excitement of getting it right (film turning out as intended) and the mistakes that are inherent to 16mm filmmaking, without the stress of having to be the perfect filmmaker. Instead, grace is given for all students to learn the medium and experiment with their own creative impulses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to articulate the causes of the local news problem and how to describe the current circumstances and consequences of the local news problem.
2) I gained insight into how the current culture and environment of the journalism landscape incentivizes some journalists to plagiarize or fabricate facts in their stories, like Stephen Glass.
3) I'm now able to better emphasize in what way the journalist of an article is biased—and I can also avow that all journalists and people are biased in some way. For example, you can be biased towards the truth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) The challenges faced by local news stations and how they are so important in our daily lives

3) The importance of a "media consumption pyramid"

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned how to think critically about the partisan divide in news and reframe my perspective. I learned how to read articles from opposing viewpoints with an open mind, and consider the bias in journalism. As someone who tries to  naively and impossibly avoid politics, I was also pushed out of my comfort zone to analyze partisan issues and consider the polarization of our news. Go narrow and deep.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Media misinformation, bias in media, problems faced by the journalism industry

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that the course struck a perfect balance between class speakers and lecturing from Bill. And throughout both mediums, we were continuously empowered as students to ask questions and contribute to the discussion. Specifically, I think the class speakers are what helped to facilitate student learning. Not only did we hear from journalists and journalist experts, but we also heard from students like us who have ventured into journalism and encountered its problems from a fresh perspective. We heard from right-wing-leaning media owners. We heard from people who were impacted by right-wing media rabbit holes firsthand. Essentially, we got a variety of perspectives on the state of journalism, and this empowered us to use these testimonies to form our own conclusions.I also think all of the writing assignments clearly signaled relevance to the class, and they helped to apply and facilitate our learning. The individual prompts were also well-timed with what we were currently learning about or where we were in the course syllabus/timeline.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was undoubtedly stimulating. The variety of guest speakers with different backgrounds and political leanings combined with the immersive lectures gave us a broad and enriched perspective on the ethical problems of journalism. Most lectures were audiovisual in nature, and the readings and writing assignments we were assigned pertained directly to how we as students consume media and the behind-the-scenes of the media we consume. Finally, we were continuously encouraged to ask and answer questions, which made the class interactive.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the world of journalism and the current issues the industry faces with trust and retaining ethical standards of content that reflect well on journalism as a whole. I also learned about different mediums of journalism and how to write better papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned a lot more about misinformation in the news, which I had not previously known a lot about.
I learned how to construct meaningful, insightful questions for guest speakers, in order to maximise what I gain from these lectures.
I developed how to write in a way that is concise and gets meaning across to the reader of my papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Better understanding of the media & journalism industry, a deep dive into some of the issues surrounding trust & polarization, writing tips, creative solutions-oriented thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical media literacy skills, ability to write lively and compelling papers, interesting approaches to media and business

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On the first day of this course, Professor Adair anonymously asked us how much news we consume on a given day... I was one of the students who consumed 0 articles/day and now I consume 5+ articles/day... all because of this class! Even though the class can be "depressing," as it explores the topic of lack of trust in journalism, it actually made me enjoy reading the news for the first time ever. Instead of reading a news article and only thinking about the subject matter of the article, I now think about how the article fits with the news outlet's business goals (ex: Athletic articles in NYT), whether it is "solutions journalism," whether it could contribute to the problem of "news avoidance," etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Entering this class I had no experience in journalism and was apprehensive of my ability to interact and engage. However, this class was an incredible introduction and inspiration to journalism. The flow of the class from the structures of journalism to innovative solutions was logical to follow. First, I gained knowledge about journalism ethics, the different types of reporting, and interviewing jargon that I will take with me into my professional career. However, these barely covered the surface of the deep insights I gained into the implications of partisan media and the challenges all media companies face. The discussions of Fox compared to CNN and MSNBC were eye-opening and going deeper into more unique media sources allowed me to interact with formats I had not seen before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed an appreciation for the role of local news in my community.
I developed an understanding of the issues facing journalism.
I learned about the different forms of journalism, both traditional and non-traditional.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

I have learned how to apply these skills in different formats of media.

response_text: To those considering taking this class... we had the coolest guest speakers of any class I have taken at Duke! David Perpich (NYT board member who led acquisition of Athletic, Wordle, etc), Jon Stewart (host of the Daily Show), Nina Jankowicz (cancelled by conservatives for leading national effort to combat mis/disinformation), Amanda Lewellyn (young alum who produces Today Explained Podcast), and so many more!

response_text: I loved the chance to engage in deep discussions about what we read. Hearing everyone's perspectives and potential solutions was great. A bit more diversity of opinion in the class might have improved discussions even more, but I think that's hard to get at Duke.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Guest speakers taught me a lot, but felt like some class lectures were not as stimulating as they could have been. Would have liked to see current events consistently integrated into slides/lectures, as opposed to just having one or two lectures dedicated to dissecting Olivia Nuzzi and Mark Robinson or the election. Also could have included pieces from the Daily Show, Fox & Friends, etc. Also, Phil Boyce was an excellent guest and I would have liked to see some more conservative speakers or assignments from/for conservative sources (though I appreciate it's probably difficult to find people willing to talk to a liberal Duke class).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some of the content assigned was very stimulating, as well as the conversations in class and questions asked to the guest speakers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated hearing the opinions of my peers and would encourage opportunities for us to talk to each other rather than at the teacher. This being said, I think we would've benefited more from group discussions and breaking off into smaller groups so that everyone was able to share their ideas and it could've been more conversational rather than one voice in a big lecture, one at a time. That would've at least been more stimulating to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thoroughly enjoyed how relevant this class was. In my experience, it is rare to be in a class in which the professor is consistently addressing current issues/events. I especially enjoyed this given the recent election cycle. Keeping up with current events is something that I value, so being able to do so through assignments, lectures, and class discussions was highly enjoyable. My only suggestion would be to make the powerpoints more engaging or perhaps limiting them altogether. Although I understand the informational value they bring, they can also not be particularly intellectually stimulating when taking up the entire class period.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I do feel fortunate as this semester felt the most important and relevant to take this class as it was in the months leading up to what feels like the most important election in our lifetimes. Everything we discussed felt perfectly timed and helped inform me to what was going on in the world around me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was amazing. I learned countless things throughout the semester, so I'll just name a few. I also learned that there is no single path to a successful career in journalism, and many successful reporters began their professional lives in other careers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
