There are three major papers, but they are only 6-7 pages and have interesting prompts. You'll learn so much about news and journalism. Tash is also very nice and clearly cares about his students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I 100% would recommend this class to everyone and anyone. They are all interesting and relate so well to the material that we cover as a class. Don't be afraid to ask the guest speakers questions. They all gave fantastic answers to our questions, and with those we were able to guide our learning in the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! This is, by far, one of my favorite courses I have ever taken at Duke. Professor Tash is phenomenal and is truly so knowledgeable and experienced in the field. You will learn so much from and his insights, while having lots of fun along the way. If you are interested in journalism, this class will expose you to so many interesting people and topics, which will undoubtedly support your development. If you are not interested in journalism as a career, you will still learn so many interesting things about an industry that impacts our society on a deep level. You will become a more critical consumer of news, and benefits from the skills learned throughout the course in your every day life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an incredible class that will allow you to understand the value of news in our society as well as the challenges facing it in the future. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the journalistic imperative of objectivity and impartiality, as well as other editorial standards and why they are so crucial.I gained insight into a wide range of current and historical topics that have played major roles in journalism and the broader world.I widened my perspective about journalism and a lot of recent developments, partially through the regular guest lectures that were informative.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing, research, synthesis. This course challenged me in ways I was not expecting. As a senior, I did not feel like I had much to learn, but the daily discussion and 3 core assignments pushed me to think deeper and produce a higher quality product.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze news to a much deeper extent. I now have a much deeper insight into how the journalism world actually works. I learned about the current landscape of the journalism world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was the best course I have ever taken at Duke. I learned how to read interresting articles, analyze news sources for credibility, and have intellectually engaging discussions about them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me to think critically about the news, engage with current events, and write concisely.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about local journalism, about journalism ethics, and about ways to make the news more optimistic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: evaluating the news more analytically, historical precedent about the news, journalism specifics from the different speakers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think above all this course taught me the importance of thinking holistically due to the fact that it gave me a greater appreciation for the process of journalism. 2 other things I learned include the importance of being articulate and up-to-date on current affairs as well as the importance of listening and trying to understand opposing viewpoints to the greatest of extents. Without opposing viewpoints, we wouldn't have journalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've learned about the structures of newspapers - how they are divided and structured. 
I have learned about what good journalism is about - having courage, curiosity, and conviction when pursuing the truth.
I've learned about the different types of journalism, from objective news reporting to morning bulletins and opinion editorials, and how journalism can shape history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically about journalism and journalistic issues; how to research and form evidence-supported opinions; the values of journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Many of the topics we explored in this course are subjects I engage with daily in my role as news editor of The Chronicle. However, I enjoyed being able to hear the varying perspectives of my peers -- many of whom do not have extensive journalism backgrounds -- on some of the ethical questions I am consistently grappling with. The subjects we discussed included how news agendas are determined and why it's important to balance the slate of coverage on a given day, the importance of anonymous sources and dangers associated with using them too frequently, the obligation to thoroughly fact-check all reporting, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how journalists think in regards to how they write, develop and produce news. One thing that I learned that stands out is that "facts are expensive, opinions are cheap." Being sure to take the time to research is important especially when crafting stories. I also learned the importance of clarity when writing and when reporting. And the importance of follow up questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the principles, economics and different mediums of journalism and how those coincide in a digital world that is constantly evolving.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The Role of Journalism in Society - What function does the news play? How has it shaped history? How do people interact with it? How has it changed?
Interdisciplinary thinking - How to approach complex challenges relating to justice and morality in a world constrained by business and personal influence 
Writing - How to edit our writing to ensure we make every word count and aren't redundant

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped a lot with my writing. Professor Tash took the time to read my paper, mark it up, and offer in-depth feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first journalism class, and I learned a ton about what the field is actually like, the types of stories produced, and how much variety there is in terms of long-form writing, TV broadcasting, podcasts, etc. This class also helped me work on my own writing skills through feedback on my essays, to just getting to read a vast collection of work over the semester and learn from those authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write in a less academic/more journalistic way, critically ask questions, and critically approach news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had know and understood the threats that journalism faces, but I learned more about the complexity and evolution of these threats. It is an insight that I will carry with me as I consume media coverage for the rest of my life. In addition to refining my media literacy skills, I developed news ways of thinking when it comes to understanding the journalism industry. It is not just newspapers and TV outlets, but a blooming industry full of startups and people who simply want to share stories that are interesting to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course did an excellent job of pushing students to think with perspective. As the semester continued on, I realized that in class discussion there was no right answer for anything we were discussing. Debating the moral ethics of journalism is no easy feat, and this class kept me engaged with the world around me, improving not just practical skills like my writing, but also helped me become more of a global citizen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Incredible insight into the journalism world and profession, both through Professor Tash's experience and the amazing speakers
- Writing development: I have never had a professor take so much time and attention in helping us write better. 
- Hearing opinions and experiences differing from mine in respectful and productive ways

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot through the course of the semester. In fact, as my first and only journalism class of college, I feel grateful it was this one. I learned to think of news as a moral battleground, and received a well-lit tour of the horizon. I learned about partisanship in the news media and to be conscious of framing. I also learned about several important stories on an international, national and local level. Most importantly, I learned about what good journalism and writing looks like, and some tips and tricks to get there.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze news academically, journalism ethics and morals, ways in which to help the journalism industry in the future

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Synthesizing readings, research and writing skills, creative and critical thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a conscious consumer of the news, how to develop my journalistic writing skills, and how to analyze different news articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a tremendous amount about the anatomy of the news business from national to local scales, the shortcomings and bright spots of the industry, and what strong, proper journalism should look like. The guest speakers were phenomenal, shedding light on some of the most pivotal moments in the history of journalism and the impact they have on our world. It was especially interesting to hear these guest speakers speak about the actual process of launching an investigation or expose of a particular subject. This class puts into perspective the indispensable role journalism plays in our society, and that we as a citizenry have an obligation to do our part to preserve that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a STEM major / not having a pub pol or journalism background, this class was super interesting! I learned about the complexities and challenges surrounding both news reporting and journalistic consumption. My favorite aspects dealt with the discussions surrounding the evolution of the news -- how topics such as fact-checking, polarization, and bias have changed drastically in the last decade and especially the last few years. The class was focused on present-day trends not history which I liked.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: the threats to journalism and it's link to the current political climate, new ways to explore better journalism in the future, the skill of clear and journalistic writing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Improved reading, writing, and reasearch skills

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analyzing news articles in depth, beyond what is expected/usually done, presenting findings well, engaging in class activities used to make us think deeply about the news that we consume.

response_text: I liked the style of the class--it was very straightforward and interactive. I particularly enjoyed the guest speakers as well as Professor Tash's ability to explain the readings in such a simple yet informative way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Paul Tash is a wonderful professor and human being - he is so passionate about the subject and his students and was always willing to meet with us outside of class. Plus he is EXTREMELY well connected and brought in incredible speakers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash is a master of this craft, and I could not be more grateful to learn from someone not only as experienced but also as compassionate as him. Given his career, he could have easily "checked out" or condescended upon our class; instead, he treated each and every person with kindness and respect. His feedback on my assignments has been invaluable, and I have truly found every aspect of this course helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the open discussions we often had in class. These allowed us to engage directly with the larger ethical questions posed by the case studies we examined in each week's readings instead of spending time reviewing the simple facts of the case, and to hear our classmates' opinions on the decisions journalists made and whether they were appropriate. The guest speakers were also phenomenal and a highlight of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: The fantastic guest speakers that we had not only demonstrated the academic strength of the JAM program and its professors, but did a great job structuring the course to connect our lectures/readings with real world speakers. The speakers allowed for connections between the current news environment and our lecture content. Moreover, they did a great job of creating segments in an 2 and a half hour long course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash created a robust environment for learning with the facilitated conversations. Most of the time, class was split into halves, one for a guest speaker, and one for discussion. In these discussion everyone came prepared, ready to discuss the materials assigned. This definitely contributed to the liveliness of the classroom, but it was Tash who kept us engaged with stories, asking us to dig deeper in our responses, and carefully choosing what material to assign to us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Milligan was one of the most helpful and knowledgeable professors I’ve had at my time at Duke- and I’m a BME major. He had a very clear and detailed lesson plan that got introductory filmmakers caught up with the more advanced students in the class, and even offered workshops on various things like lighting, camera work, and editing throughout the year to bolster our learning. I think it was so cool we were able to use the film studio for every class, as instead of just watching and discussing film pieces we were able to create and learn as we made film together.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got a lot better at my craft. Getting to practice it for a whole semester, following my own methodology, is amazing and such a privilege!I learned how to present my progress. Progress comes in all forms, and sometimes it isn't as tangible or immediately noticeable so it must be communicated verbally instead. But this communication, whether it is in the form of a Powerpoint or spoken word, is important so that the class can give good feedback and my involvement is still evident.I learned how to plan a semester-long project from start to finish. I've never done something like this before because the longest project I've ever completed was about half a semester long, with pre-made guidelines. Writing my own syllabus was a new exercise for me. I also learned how to set goals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think the skill I most developed over the course of this semester was self-discipline. In creating my short film, I really had to organize my time effectively and motivate myself to keep on track, and I felt like this course helped us structure the development of this skill well. I also learned a lot about the process of production and all the little administrative tasks that go into making a film. Finally, I got better at presenting unfinished works in front of people. Normally, in the past, I would only ever show finished works. However, to receive valuable feedback, I have realized that showing progress to people along the way is really important.

Her engagement and excitement regarding class topics showed alongside her expertise and connections in the industry, further promoting a positive and constructive learning environment. The prompts given for film creation were very helpful in order to both incite creative thinking, stretch the limits of our creativity, and encourage the development of the skilled discussed and sometimes practiced in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
In class screening of students assignments is really helpful because I get to see what my classmates are making and get inspired from it. I also get to ask questions that deepen my understanding and vocabulary of filmmaking. 
I like the assignments with different theme because it helps give structure to the projects and allow us to explore a specific theme relating to dance film, also helps supply us with inspiration and new ideas about dance film. I can also build on the skills I learnt during these assignments for my final. 
It is also helpful for me to watch people react to my film and hear their feedback on my work. 
I think the movement exercises is very helpful for class. It helps bond everyone together and makes students focus on class. It is also helpful for us to think more about dance and movement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Art is a creative process. Tho theory are important but feels are the most valuable thing, so it is intellectually stimulating, and in a unexplainable way

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very stimulating. Each film we made challenged me to think outside of the box and push myself.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was fantastic!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I knew basically nothing about film at the beginning of the class and can now confidently say that I can direct, film, and edit a video successfully. I really loved our class times, especially when we did physical activities to facilitate learning and the integration of concepts we were being made to understand.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class is stimulating because it introduces a new type of film to filmmakers and a new type of dance to dancers. It is special because it focuses on a genre that is not widely known in both community and teaches students how to combine the best of both worlds.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!!!!!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Lovely course, be excited to make films!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The professor is a very sweet and creative soul, and she's really good at pushing you to grow as a filmmaker and person. She's also super constructive and gentle, and I really appreciated her class - it was like a once-a-week creative break from the chaos of other Duke classes, and she provided a welcoming environment to learn about dance film and try new things with cameras and film-making.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This a wonderful class with a great instructor who has so much knowledge and is so willing to help and encourage you in your creative endeavors. Even if you know absolutely nothing about filmmaking or editing, the class will teach you and the instructor support you in your learning. I'd recommend it to anyone who is looking to learn film in an unconventional way/environment or even just learn a new way to see/create film.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is very interesting and would be of great help to both filmmakers and dancers alike as it helps expand our knowledge of both fields. The class is very beginner friendly, anyone who has no experience in both fields will find it easy to learn if they put their heart into it, along with some hardwork. The instructor is very open minded and encourages all sorts of creativity, in addition to giving suggestions on how to improve. She is also very kind and flexible and allows students to engage however they would like too while ensuring everyone feels included.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a new understanding of how to film dance films. I had absolutely no knowledge previously, so it was very fun to have that new experience

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed cinematography skill, video editing skill, and the ability to analyze films/dance films/documentary

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1- I expanded my idea of what it means to be a dance film. What can be considered a dance film? What can be considered dance? This course has showed me that there is so much more to movement and capturing movement than people usually think.
2- I learned to find inspiration in other peoples' works. Throughout the course, I watched the works of my classmates, which have been amazing, and as I learned more about their experiences, I learned to reinterpret my own and express them through film.
3- Collaboration is necessary. Dance film is the kind of hybrid work that requires working across different fields, therefore bridging them and that connection can only be me through other people.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learning about dance film as a genre of film. 
2. How can documentary and dance film be integrated together.
3. Practice of making dance film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I obtained skills for analyzing Shakespeare, discussing Shakespeare, and viewing adaptations critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had a casual interest in Shakespeare prior to this course, but this course taught me to really dive deeply into his works in ways I have not before. I learned a lot about the historical context behind Shakespeare plays and how that context can be recontextualized through adaptation for a modern audience. I really enjoyed this class as a means of thinking more deeply about film as a medium and how it connects to more historical mediums like plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close and wide engagement with Shakespeare in text, across genre/culture in adaptation through various mediums, and written articulation of thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about film techniques (sound, camera angles, mise en scene, etc.) which I did not know much about before
2. I learned about the different definitions of what it means for a movie to be an "adaptation" of something and that adaptations are not merely derivative of the text
3. I learned how to closely analyze the language Shakespeare uses throughout his texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze films which is something I've never done before, especially putting them in conversation with texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I never know what to write for this question because it is hard to come up with a new method or skill you learn in every class. I really enjoyed all of the plays though. I suppose something I learned was just how much Shakespeare recycled themes and character tropes. I think it was fun to be able to see traces of his different plays bleeding into each other a little.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We went deep into analyzing Shakespeare texts as well as adaptations. I had never engaged with films like we did in this class, using cinematic terminology to discuss and analyze them. I think overall this made me more observant and a better reader/thinker.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze Shakespeare, Shakespearian films, and how to discuss aspects of Shakespearian literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about film techniques and terminology as well as read some scholarship on films (e.g. Mulvey's 'male gaze' theory). I read and reflected on a diverse range of Shakespeare plays and how they can be adapted into different times and cultures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the freedom we have in when to submit our written responses and what we could write about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the use of "gobbets" as a means of prompting analysis. They're a relatively low-stakes way to engage with whatever we're reading or watching, and I really enjoyed getting the feedback on it. It always felt like our professor was really interested in whatever we wrote about and why it struck us in particular. I also really enjoyed the balance between watching clips to spark discussion and letting us guide discussion naturally through conversation with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek does such an incredible job at facilitating open discussion - he takes everyone's points seriously and is clearly so informed/knowledgeable on these plays. Writing our gobbets (reading responses, 8 total at any point in the semester) allowed me to synthesize my thoughts across the plays and their adaptations, and they were really accessible ways with engaging closely with the week's topics. Derek really made this class so fun, and his selections of the readings/plays/films were fantastic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek made the course extremely conversational, allowing me to develop different perspectives on each text we read and movie we saw. He encouraged people to disagree with him, which left lots of room for independent analytical thought. I would keep this teaching style for future classes. Additionally, watching a variety of different Shakespeare adaptations, some strict and some loose, facilitated my understanding of what it means for a film to be an adaptation. I would continue showing films from different time periods and cultures in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought Derek found a wonderful balance between lecture and seminar, which is something I've struggled with in classes before. He always asked questions to prompt discussion, but also started each class with a 5 ish minute lecture that help put the lesson into context. I absolutely loved this course and think Derek would make a wonderful professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned a lot more about misinformation in the news, which I had not previously known a lot about.
I learned how to construct meaningful, insightful questions for guest speakers, in order to maximise what I gain from these lectures.
I developed how to write in a way that is concise and gets meaning across to the reader of my papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Better understanding of the media & journalism industry, a deep dive into some of the issues surrounding trust & polarization, writing tips, creative solutions-oriented thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical media literacy skills, ability to write lively and compelling papers, interesting approaches to media and business

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On the first day of this course, Professor Adair anonymously asked us how much news we consume on a given day... I was one of the students who consumed 0 articles/day and now I consume 5+ articles/day... all because of this class! Even though the class can be "depressing," as it explores the topic of lack of trust in journalism, it actually made me enjoy reading the news for the first time ever. Instead of reading a news article and only thinking about the subject matter of the article, I now think about how the article fits with the news outlet's business goals (ex: Athletic articles in NYT), whether it is "solutions journalism," whether it could contribute to the problem of "news avoidance," etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Entering this class I had no experience in journalism and was apprehensive of my ability to interact and engage. However, this class was an incredible introduction and inspiration to journalism. The flow of the class from the structures of journalism to innovative solutions was logical to follow. First, I gained knowledge about journalism ethics, the different types of reporting, and interviewing jargon that I will take with me into my professional career. However, these barely covered the surface of the deep insights I gained into the implications of partisan media and the challenges all media companies face. The discussions of Fox compared to CNN and MSNBC were eye-opening and going deeper into more unique media sources allowed me to interact with formats I had not seen before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I developed an appreciation for the role of local news in my community.
I developed an understanding of the issues facing journalism.
I learned about the different forms of journalism, both traditional and non-traditional.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I think I learned how to navigate the media more vigilantly. 
I definitely developed deeper critical thinking skills when it comes to how I consume news or "the media". 
I have learned how to apply these skills in different formats of media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the foundations of journalism and journalistic principles, the necessary role fact-checking plays in journalism as well as in our larger democracy, and the evolution of the journalism industry as well as the threats it currently faces.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to better write (especially in a journalistic style)! I also better developed my research and data visualization skills.

response_text: I think the learning environment is great. Very engaging and interactive from both students and professor Adair. I think the guest lecture part of this class is what makes it great. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the method of having a discussion section in canvas to add in questions ahead of guest speakers helped facilitate learning, it helped me learn the maximum amount from each lecturer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the mix of lectures and guest speakers. Both were interesting and informative in different ways, and class was never boring or predictable. The on background/on the record lecture was great, and I really enjoyed the chance to hear David Perpich. Phil Boyce was also really interesting to talk to as someone with a conservative take on the media landscape.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: To those considering taking this class... we had the coolest guest speakers of any class I have taken at Duke! David Perpich (NYT board member who led acquisition of Athletic, Wordle, etc), Jon Stewart (host of the Daily Show), Nina Jankowicz (cancelled by conservatives for leading national effort to combat mis/disinformation), Amanda Lewellyn (young alum who produces Today Explained Podcast), and so many more!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the organization of the course was very influential in allowing discussion to build deeper facilitating specifically to students who may be taking this course as their first one in journalism. The introduction to ethics, types of journalism, and the leaders in media helped gain a base of knowledge and sources I was able to develop as I continued in the course. The lead into partisan media allowed the issues of today to be addressed which was critical. Finally, concluding with the innovation and future of journalism allowed me to leave this course both intrigued and inspired.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the guest speakers and learned a lot from them. I also appreciated the lectures that incorporated marginalized communities and their role in journalism, and the classes on local journalism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because of the creative class environment, lively debates, and speakers. It lacked a bit of academic rigor, however. More papers or readings that we engage with directly during class could have heightened the quality of some of our discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Challenging status quo of journalism and reflecting on how we can improve journalism and products of journalism.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating due to the wide variety of speakers and topics discussed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved the chance to engage in deep discussions about what we read. Hearing everyone's perspectives and potential solutions was great. A bit more diversity of opinion in the class might have improved discussions even more, but I think that's hard to get at Duke.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Guest speakers taught me a lot, but felt like some class lectures were not as stimulating as they could have been. Would have liked to see current events consistently integrated into slides/lectures, as opposed to just having one or two lectures dedicated to dissecting Olivia Nuzzi and Mark Robinson or the election. Also could have included pieces from the Daily Show, Fox & Friends, etc. Also, Phil Boyce was an excellent guest and I would have liked to see some more conservative speakers or assignments from/for conservative sources (though I appreciate it's probably difficult to find people willing to talk to a liberal Duke class).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The range of topics from local to big media and specifically the interaction with guest speakers made it very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some of the content assigned was very stimulating, as well as the conversations in class and questions asked to the guest speakers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated hearing the opinions of my peers and would encourage opportunities for us to talk to each other rather than at the teacher. This being said, I think we would've benefited more from group discussions and breaking off into smaller groups so that everyone was able to share their ideas and it could've been more conversational rather than one voice in a big lecture, one at a time. That would've at least been more stimulating to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thoroughly enjoyed how relevant this class was. In my experience, it is rare to be in a class in which the professor is consistently addressing current issues/events. I especially enjoyed this given the recent election cycle. Keeping up with current events is something that I value, so being able to do so through assignments, lectures, and class discussions was highly enjoyable. My only suggestion would be to make the powerpoints more engaging or perhaps limiting them altogether. Although I understand the informational value they bring, they can also not be particularly intellectually stimulating when taking up the entire class period.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I do feel fortunate as this semester felt the most important and relevant to take this class as it was in the months leading up to what feels like the most important election in our lifetimes. Everything we discussed felt perfectly timed and helped inform me to what was going on in the world around me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take the course with Bill if you're specifically interested in his work with fact checking because that ends up taking a good chunk of the class. This is not the most rigorous course but it is unique in its level of exposure to great speakers and untouched topics of trust and business in media.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to be more informed about politics and journalism you should take this class. Opens your eyes to what is out there and keeps you informed on how to consume news the right way. I believe this is a very important skill to have especially as a young adult going through college and hopefully an election year like we did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy it! And speak a lot more in class, I think that proves to be quite important.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class! It might be my favorite at Duke so far (and it convinced me to declare a journalism minor).  Bill is a fantastic professor who makes lectures fun and will introduce you to a variety of interesting topics. You'll learn a lot about media and meet super cool people in the industry. I also made good friends in the class thanks to the small-group environment and open discussions. As an added bonus, the workload was always very manageable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have any mild interest in journalism or want to just try it out this course is perfect to begin. It allows you to gain so much knowledge about media and dive into all the complexities and implications. My bet is even if you start with a small interest in journalism you will definitely end with a large one after taking this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT! You absolutely will not regret it. This has been my favorite class and professor I have ever had in my four years at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

ALSO this class made me so much more aware of the news, and I think the news quizzes were such a great idea and absolutely essential to the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that it was pretty stimulating as it is, but I think at times debates felt a little one-sided or simple. I don't think this is the fault of the professor but more the class makeup -- it was dominated by students with the same ideologies getting their news from large papers that skewed left of center. Maybe in order to combat this, more of the readings could be from conservative outlets or perhaps "extra credit" of not only keeping up with Reliable Sources/The Morning but also regularly consuming news from right-leaning papers. Not sure how feasible that is but an idea.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This might be a controversial take – and I hate to suggest more quizzes – but I think that if there were more news quizzes that were shorter and more frequent (but still worth a relatively small part of our grade), that would be more incentive to pay attention to headlines throughout the semester, rather than cramming right before. Also, they're fun. And if the stakes are relatively low, I think it would be beneficial.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: take it! I think it's important for everyone, on an academic, cultural, and personal standpoint

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Frank Bruni is a legend, and you should take any class with him that you can. More than just his direct insights, he has access to incredible guest speakers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will not practice journalistic writing in this class. This class is a discussion of current events and how political climates shape the media. If you do not like talking about political polarization, do not take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I loved taking this with Professor Bruni! He was a wonderful professor, a great orator, and a kind person. He is so incredibly knowledgeable about the journalism world and I really valued the opportunity to learn from him.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to really think about political issues from both sides, to be as finely detailed as possible in my writing (reading it over and over again), and to come up with good questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my writing skills, learned more about the process of journalism, and understood the role of the media in our world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave unparalleled insight into the world of news and its impact on the public and policy. More specifically, I learned about the business of the news world, the struggle in maintaining local news, and the polarization in the news world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course. I improved my journalistic writing but more notably I improved my idea generation when planning papers. In receiving one of my lower grades at Duke, I learned how to take constructive criticism on a piece of writing and turn it around for the next assignment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding of how to view larger themes in news. I also developed a thorough understanding of the problems in the current news landscape and the decline of local news. I also developed an understanding of the ethical issues underlying journalism and the journalistic process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course, specifically about critical analysis and discussion. I also thought this was a great opportunity to write more creatively, though sometimes I struggled with this writing style.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to synthesize news amidst such partisanship, learn from impressive guest speakers, and how to have healthy political discourse in a class environment in a respectful way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really developed my writing skills, particularly in regards to informative but casual writing. I feel as though this was the first class I have taken which emphasizes writing for readbility, understanding and enjoyment which I think is really important. I also learned a lot about how the news is the lens through which we view our democracy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Writing with concision 
Analyzing differing perspectives and engaging in respectful dialogue 
Skills and mindsets reporters need, whether in investigative journalism, local news, etc

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
The importance of keeping up with the news
How to ask thoughtful questions of guest speakers
That journalism and local news is dwindling (and ways we can save it)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have never been more informed on the news than I have been in this class. I learned about how local news is dying and the younger population prefers to get a lot of their news from social media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the ethics of journalism, the underlying factors that contribute to its eficacy or lack thereof, and what can be done to make the institution of journnalism better.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The legal and ethical protocols for journalism; how journalistic enterprises function as businesses; how to better recognize biases in journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how important it is to report against your beliefs and stay quick on your feet in this industry. Being part of the news gives you tremendous power, and it is your absolute responsibility to not fall into easy ways of thinking but rather constantly confer with others, challenge yourself, and make bold decisions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learn all about the news industry. Through the coruse readings, guest speakers and discussion topics, I recognized the important role that news has played and currently plays in our society. I also developed a critical thought process when consuming news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was amazing. I learned countless things throughout the semester, so I'll just name a few. First, I learned that objectivity is a difficult ideal to achieve in journalism, and the closest we can get to total objectivity is by reporting against our own biases and hypotheses. I also learned that there is no single path to a successful career in journalism, and many successful reporters began their professional lives in other careers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The intersection between journalism and community-building. 
2. How the news functions as a first draft of history which is why journalistic practices of fairness and truth-seeking are so important. 
3. Ways journalism can distinguish itself in an increasingly crowded media environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: lots of insights from acclaimed guest speakers in the journalism field, knowledge about the troubles facing the news industry today, knowledge about the values and principles that journalism ought to embody

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned virtually everything about journalism as an industry, and what it means to be a great journalist. I had never taken a journalism class before, so a lot of the material that we covered was completely new to me. I learned so much about the importance of preserving this industry, and what it really takes to be a journalist during this day and age. I learned how to make my writing more muscular, the importance of collecting trustworthy sources, and the type of commitment that it really takes to be a journalist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much is this wonderful course. I learned how about effective and honest journalism and its societal importance. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze news to a much deeper extent. I now have a much deeper insight into how the journalism world actually works. I learned about the current landscape of the journalism world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was the best course I have ever taken at Duke. I learned how to read interresting articles, analyze news sources for credibility, and have intellectually engaging discussions about them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me to think critically about the news, engage with current events, and write concisely.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about local journalism, about journalism ethics, and about ways to make the news more optimistic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: evaluating the news more analytically, historical precedent about the news, journalism specifics from the different speakers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think above all this course taught me the importance of thinking holistically due to the fact that it gave me a greater appreciation for the process of journalism. 2 other things I learned include the importance of being articulate and up-to-date on current affairs as well as the importance of listening and trying to understand opposing viewpoints to the greatest of extents. Without opposing viewpoints, we wouldn't have journalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've learned about the structures of newspapers - how they are divided and structured. 
I have learned about what good journalism is about - having courage, curiosity, and conviction when pursuing the truth.
I've learned about the different types of journalism, from objective news reporting to morning bulletins and opinion editorials, and how journalism can shape history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think critically about journalism and journalistic issues; how to research and form evidence-supported opinions; the values of journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Many of the topics we explored in this course are subjects I engage with daily in my role as news editor of The Chronicle. However, I enjoyed being able to hear the varying perspectives of my peers -- many of whom do not have extensive journalism backgrounds -- on some of the ethical questions I am consistently grappling with. The subjects we discussed included how news agendas are determined and why it's important to balance the slate of coverage on a given day, the importance of anonymous sources and dangers associated with using them too frequently, the obligation to thoroughly fact-check all reporting, and much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how journalists think in regards to how they write, develop and produce news. One thing that I learned that stands out is that "facts are expensive, opinions are cheap." Being sure to take the time to research is important especially when crafting stories. I also learned the importance of clarity when writing and when reporting. And the importance of follow up questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the principles, economics and different mediums of journalism and how those coincide in a digital world that is constantly evolving.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The Role of Journalism in Society - What function does the news play? How has it shaped history? How do people interact with it? How has it changed?
Interdisciplinary thinking - How to approach complex challenges relating to justice and morality in a world constrained by business and personal influence 
Writing - How to edit our writing to ensure we make every word count and aren't redundant

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped a lot with my writing. Professor Tash took the time to read my paper, mark it up, and offer in-depth feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first journalism class, and I learned a ton about what the field is actually like, the types of stories produced, and how much variety there is in terms of long-form writing, TV broadcasting, podcasts, etc. This class also helped me work on my own writing skills through feedback on my essays, to just getting to read a vast collection of work over the semester and learn from those authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write in a less academic/more journalistic way, critically ask questions, and critically approach news.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had know and understood the threats that journalism faces, but I learned more about the complexity and evolution of these threats. It is an insight that I will carry with me as I consume media coverage for the rest of my life. In addition to refining my media literacy skills, I developed news ways of thinking when it comes to understanding the journalism industry. It is not just newspapers and TV outlets, but a blooming industry full of startups and people who simply want to share stories that are interesting to them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course did an excellent job of pushing students to think with perspective. As the semester continued on, I realized that in class discussion there was no right answer for anything we were discussing. Debating the moral ethics of journalism is no easy feat, and this class kept me engaged with the world around me, improving not just practical skills like my writing, but also helped me become more of a global citizen.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Incredible insight into the journalism world and profession, both through Professor Tash's experience and the amazing speakers
- Writing development: I have never had a professor take so much time and attention in helping us write better. 
- Hearing opinions and experiences differing from mine in respectful and productive ways

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot through the course of the semester. In fact, as my first and only journalism class of college, I feel grateful it was this one. I learned to think of news as a moral battleground, and received a well-lit tour of the horizon. I learned about partisanship in the news media and to be conscious of framing. I also learned about several important stories on an international, national and local level. Most importantly, I learned about what good journalism and writing looks like, and some tips and tricks to get there.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze news academically, journalism ethics and morals, ways in which to help the journalism industry in the future

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Synthesizing readings, research and writing skills, creative and critical thinking

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a conscious consumer of the news, how to develop my journalistic writing skills, and how to analyze different news articles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a tremendous amount about the anatomy of the news business from national to local scales, the shortcomings and bright spots of the industry, and what strong, proper journalism should look like. The guest speakers were phenomenal, shedding light on some of the most pivotal moments in the history of journalism and the impact they have on our world. It was especially interesting to hear these guest speakers speak about the actual process of launching an investigation or expose of a particular subject. This class puts into perspective the indispensable role journalism plays in our society, and that we as a citizenry have an obligation to do our part to preserve that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a STEM major / not having a pub pol or journalism background, this class was super interesting! I learned about the complexities and challenges surrounding both news reporting and journalistic consumption. My favorite aspects dealt with the discussions surrounding the evolution of the news -- how topics such as fact-checking, polarization, and bias have changed drastically in the last decade and especially the last few years. The class was focused on present-day trends not history which I liked.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: the threats to journalism and it's link to the current political climate, new ways to explore better journalism in the future, the skill of clear and journalistic writing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Improved reading, writing, and reasearch skills

response_text: Analyzing news articles in depth, beyond what is expected/usually done, presenting findings well, engaging in class activities used to make us think deeply about the news that we consume.

response_text: Professor Tash is a master of this craft, and I could not be more grateful to learn from someone not only as experienced but also as compassionate as him. Given his career, he could have easily "checked out" or condescended upon our class; instead, he treated each and every person with kindness and respect. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the open discussions we often had in class. These allowed us to engage directly with the larger ethical questions posed by the case studies we examined in each week's readings instead of spending time reviewing the simple facts of the case, and to hear our classmates' opinions on the decisions journalists made and whether they were appropriate. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Tash created a robust environment for learning with the facilitated conversations. Most of the time, class was split into halves, one for a guest speaker, and one for discussion. In these discussion everyone came prepared, ready to discuss the materials assigned. This definitely contributed to the liveliness of the classroom, but it was Tash who kept us engaged with stories, asking us to dig deeper in our responses, and carefully choosing what material to assign to us.

response_text: Professor Tash comes into the semester with a goal: to make this one of the most memorable classes of your college experience.
